text: ROSA FLORES: So in
become undocumented overnight?

ELIAS ROSENFELD:
Overnight, yeah.

ROSA FLORES: Elias Rosenfeld
was seven when he came to the US

from Venezuela on a visa, which
was dependent on his mom's work
visa.

A few years later, his mom
Annabella died of cancer.

ELIAS ROSENFELD: Her presence
though is constantly felt.
I feel it all the time.
I feel her energy.

ROSA FLORES: And to make
matters worse, in middle school

he learned that without his
mom, he was undocumented.

ELIAS ROSENFELD:
You're literally

standing in the country
that does not want you,

and you want to be so
hard part of this country.

ELIAS ROSENFELD: Hope came
his high school freshman year,

when President Obama issued an
executive order known as DACA,

giving about 750,000
people like Elias,

who were brought to the US
as children, a work permit.

He earned a full scholarship
to Brandeis University,

but says that hope
came crashing down when
Donald Trump became president.

ELIAS ROSENFELD: The very
little protections you used
to have are gone overnight.

ROSA FLORES: And while President
Trump's executive orders

on immigration exempted
DACA, the detention

of this former DACA
recipient in Mississippi--

- Today, my father and brother
await deportation, while--

ROSA FLORES: After she told
her immigration story publicly,

has Elias, who has published
multiple op-eds in his college

paper, and other
vocal immigrants

around the country feeling added
fear that they could be next.

ELIAS ROSENFELD:
It's very painful.

It's a sense of a lack
of security in a country
that you should feel secure in.

ROSA FLORES:
Fueling the anxiety,

tweets posted by ICE
this week saying,

DACA is not a
protected legal status.

Deferred action may be
revoked any time, especially
when someone commits a crime.

The Congressional
Hispanic Caucus

releasing a scathing
statement, with Representative

Gutierrez calling the move,
quote, "disgusting behavior."

LUIS GUTIERREZ: I was
very saddened and almost

heartbroken to hear that
Homeland Security to a Twitter

account would say to 750,000
young people in this country,
you're no longer safe.

ROSA FLORES: ICE is not
commenting about the concerns

of the Congressional
Hispanic Caucus,

instead reiterating to CNN
the content of the tweets.

For Elias, who
wouldn't be battling

possible deportation
had his mom not
lost her battle with cancer--
Do you miss her though?

ELIAS ROSENFELD:
All the time, yeah.
It's rough.

ROSA FLORES: He
asks President Trump

to create a path for citizenship
for young people like himself

who, by all accounts, feel
American in the only country
they really know.
Rosa Flores, CNN, Boston.
